Article.ArticleTitle: Changes in Ozone Chemical Sensitivity in the United States from 2007 to 2016.

AbstractText: Anthropogenic nitrogen oxide (NO<sub>x</sub>) and volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions in the U.S. have declined substantially over the last decade, altering the NO<sub>x</sub>-VOC chemistry and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) production characteristics of many areas. In this work we use multiple air quality analysis tools to assess how these large reductions in NO<sub>x</sub> and VOC have affected O<sub>3</sub> production regimes across the U.S. between 2007 and 2016. We first compare observed and modeled evolution of NO<sub>x</sub>-limited and NO<sub>x</sub>-saturated O<sub>3</sub> formation regimes using a day-of-week (DOW) analysis. This comparison builds confidence in the model's ability to qualitatively capture O<sub>3</sub> changes due to chemistry and meteorology both within years and across periods of large emissions decreases. DOW analysis, however, cannot definitively differentiate between emissions and meteorology impacts. We therefore supplement this analysis with sensitivity calculations from CAMx-HDDM to characterize modeled shifts in O<sub>3</sub> formation chemistry between 2007 and 2016 in different regions of the U.S. We also conduct a more detailed investigation of the O<sub>3</sub> chemical behavior observed in Chicago and Detroit, two complex urban areas in the Midwest. Both the ambient and modeling data show that more locations across the U.S. have shifted towards NO<sub>x</sub>-limited regimes between 2007 and 2016. The model-based HDDM sensitivity analysis shows only a few locations remaining NO<sub>x</sub>-saturated on high-O<sub>3</sub> days in 2016 including portions of New York City, Chicago, Minneapolis, San Francisco and Los Angeles. This work offers insights into the current state of O<sub>3</sub> production chemistry in large population centers across the U.S., as well as how O<sub>3</sub> chemistry in these areas may evolve in the future.
